discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
key is: without affecting any existing services
So define new service on TCP80 with no session-ttl expire. Make new FW policy and place above other HTTP policy

Selected Answer: BC
This need some testing, I would go with B and C, reference: https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortigate/6.4.0/new-features/743069/no-session-timeout

comments.content: Just a new HTTP service and policy above the existing one will not change anything without the session-ttl set to never or increased to max. CD seems like the most correct out of these.
Thing is if you just set it to max, you're not preventing the session from expiring it just takes longer
@Babnav, you can configure TTL for service objects in the CLI

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
I would go with B and C
https://community.fortinet.com/t5/FortiGate/Technical-Tip-Session-timeout-settings/ta-p/191228

questions.question_text:
An administrator has a requirement to keep an application session from timing out on port 80.
What two changes can the administrator make to resolve the issue without affecting any existing services running through FortiGate? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Set the TTL value to never under config system-ttl.
choices.B: Create a new firewall policy with the new HTTP service and place it above the existing HTTP policy.
choices.D: Set the session TTL on the HTTP policy to maximum.
choices.C: Create a new service object for HTTP service and set the session TTL to never.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
FG security 7 pag 551

questions.question_text: Which security feature does FortiGate provide to protect servers located in the internal networks from attacks such as SQL injections?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Flow-based inspection

Question repeated with Q96

Reference and download study guide:
https://ebin.pub/fortinet-fortigate-security-study-guide-for-fortios-72.html
https://ebin.pub/fortinet-fortigate-infrastructure-study-guide-for-fortios-72.html

Selected Answer: B
Answer is B

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

Based on the administrator profile settings, what permissions must the administrator set to run the diagnose firewall auth list CLI command on
FortiGate?

An administrator has configured outgoing interface any in a firewall policy.
Which statement is true about the policy list view?

choices.D: By Sequence view will be disabled.
choices.A: Interface Pair view will be disabled.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Study Guide – FW Policies – Managing FW Policies – Policy List – Interface Pair View and By Sequence.

FW policies appear in an organized list. The list is organized either in Interface Pair View or By Sequence. 

Usually, the list will appear in Interface Pair View. Each section contains policies for that ingress-egress pair. Alternatively, you can view your policies as a single, comprehensive list by selecting By Sequence at the top of the page.

In some cases, you won’t have a choice of which view is used.

If you use multiple source or destination interfaces, or the any interface, in a FW policy, policies cannot be separated into sections by interface pairs – some would be triplets or more.

Selected Answer: A
"If you use multiple source or destination interfaces, or the any interface in a firewall policy, you cannot separate policies into sections by interface pairs—some would be triplets or more. So instead, policies are then always displayed in a single list (By Sequence)."

Fortigate Security Study Guide v7.0, Page 129

Selected Answer: A
Reference and download study guide:
https://ebin.pub/fortinet-fortigate-security-study-guide-for-fortios-72.html
